CONCEPT: The concept is to make one continuous timelapse shot following the night and day sky over the span of an entire day, 24 hours. The film is called “Warm Earth, Which I’ve Been Told” and is built around music by Six Organs of Admittance, who have generously given me their full support and music rights for this film. The entire film will be shot on a digital camera with a 180º circular fisheye lens (brand new Canon lens technology), allowing the entire horizon and sky to be visible in frame. 
The fisheye will contain the images in a circle, representing the shape of the earth, a repeating theme throughout the film. Likewise the distortion of a fisheye lens will add an interesting abstractness to the images making an entirely unique and compelling work of art. 
PREVIOUS TIMELAPSE: With the success of my timelapse art film, Mossgrove/Bed of Moss, this new film will continue to expand the creative parameters of timelapse storytelling through dramatic photography, deliberate pacing, style and mood.  
STORY: It begins at noon looking straight up at the sun and sky. Trees stretch from the outside of the circle toward the center where they part, displaying the entire sky. Voices chant “where will I rest” as the sun continues to set and clouds flow by. At the 4:50 mark, the sun sets behind the horizon. Then the music shifts to a tranquil/cosmic section. Here the camera will display the entire rotating night sky and Milky Way galaxy, silhouetted by lunging trees. At 12:50 in the film, the music begins to shift again into an ominous chant as the sun starts to rise. The camera follows the sun up above at noon under the trees at the same place where the film began (representing the looping/spherical pattern of life).
FUNDING: To help pay for and recoup the costs for making the film. Those include rental costs of the camera, lens, battery and data storage for shooting 24 hours straight in a remote location. For $2,000 I will able to produce, film, edit, and complete this unique HD film that will be shown throughout the world.
PUBLIC SCREENINGS:
FESTIVALS: I have had my films shown in over 30 international film festivals and plan to use those connections to screen this film in many festivals around the world.
PLANETARIUMS: I am already in discussion with screening this in many planetariums and welcome the opportunity to inspire and educate audiences with this unique glimpse of a day passing.
ONLINE: I will offer a full HD version of the film available free online with vimeo.

updates.update_content:
The film is finished and is available free to view in HD online in its entirety. Two years of planning, over 100,000 pictures taken in rain/sun/stars/trees, to make a unique planetary experience.
play>like>share>tip>repeat
97,687 pictures taken and 8 day staring at the sky. There are still a few more days to go, just waiting for the perfect day to get those final scenes. Here is a teaser of the film COMING SOON

I went out today and found a location that works better. This will be an ideal place to photograph, it is far away from any people, with large lush trees, and a good window to the sky. In this image it was raining, which I am fine with at times during the day. That will look interesting in timelapse, but I want to make sure the sky is clear at night to see the stars. 
I also started mocking up some design ideas. I like how this feels similar to a planet floating in space.

I think I found an interesting location. This is the most like the sketch I made and is in Siuslaw National Forest with stunning large growth trees. Only thing that worries me is this is very close to the pacific ocean and the climate rains almost daily, plus I wonder if this canopy is too closed and won't be interesting enough in timelapse. It still could be interesting to see the lighting shifts throughout the day with small slots of stars around the silhouetted trees at night. 
If I get a break in the weather I will give this location a try and go from there. I'm also considering adding some graphics and animation to the images to make it more interesting and with a little story structure.

I've been experimenting with the fisheye lens and locations and come to a decision. The most interesting image is in the woods. Initially I was thinking about having more of an open canopy to see the sky and stars with maybe a few trees in the frame. While hiking for locations at remote lakes I started photographing in the forest and noticed that this lens fits perfectly for photographing trees. Trees have always been an almost impossible thing to photograph because you are never able to capture the scale of being under them in a typical photograph. However this fisheye lens is able to show the entire tree from the base to the top and capture the feeling of being under these towering pillars of life.

Hello kickstarter friends. First, thank you to everyone for making my campaign successful. I have begun location scouting and made some tests and am excited about the images I've captured. Still haven't found the perfect location or day to capture but soon enough with patience it will all come together. Until then enjoy these images.
Thank you.
Kurtis

As the Spark Flies Upward is a novel centered around four generations of a family living on the banks of a river in the Depression-era south.  Specifically, the story follows the lives of Grace Canton Kelley, her sister Athena, and their two best friends as they respond to the turmoil caused by an alcoholic, abusive stepfather and the poverty and dangers that surround their town.  The story is told from the perspective of Grace, the meek, bookish second-born, who grows up in the shadow of her magical, beautiful, yet dangerous elder sister.  Grace's timidity and lack of self-confidence are only surpassed by her passion to protect those she loves and the burden of responsibility she feels to hold her family together. 
The book visits the unspoken, unyielding bond of loyalty between siblings, yet highlights the stark contrast between Grace and Athena, shown perhaps most vividly by the way they ultimately deal with the abuse of their mother.  Most of all, the book offers a poignant look at the problem of evil and its lasting reverberations within the intertwined fates of a family.  As the Spark Flies Upward is a compelling story filled with love, laughter, pain, grief, vengeance, forgiveness, and hope.  You should read it.
The funds raised on Kickstarter will be used for cover design, publication and preliminary promotion of this book, all of which are entering final stages.  The headshots and book cover photos are in the capable hands of Lauren Stonestreet and the book cover is currently in Heidi Rolf's design studio (keep a weather eye on my website for a sneak peek in the coming weeks).  The video you see above was filmed by Stephen Stonestreet, and he and Lauren are tag-teaming my online presence, which is off to a great start.  There are a few more details to handle with our publishing company (Round Door Publishing) and setting up the title with our distributor (Lightning Source/Ingram) that will also necessitate some bucks. The book will be offered in paperback and eBook formats, so there will be absolutely no excuse for any living humans not to read it.  
The key in this whole process is that I've been surrounded with young, hip professionals that know what they are doing. That has made all the difference. Now, please help me pay them what they deserve!
The book launch is planned for late June 2011, and we plan to do it right...and with your help, we can.  Thanks for your support, whether in word or green!!!  (Please check out the prizes to the right when deciding how many zeros to add to your donation.)

Hi everybody in Kickstarter-land! 
SCROLL DOWN FOR AN INSIDER LOOK INTO THE PROCESS OF THE CARRIERS!
My name is Kevin D. Bandt http://kevinbandtconcepts.blogspot.com/ and I write and draw the comic The Carriers. It is a fully painted comic about monsters, magic and all the things that I find awesome. I have been working on the comic every night after work. 
I went to the University of Wisconsin-Whitewater where I received a BFA in Illustration. My idea was that I would get into the video game industry then work on comics at night. Unfortunately that didn't happen. I have taken work outside of the art/illustration world but that hasn't stopped me from putting out comics. 
I have released 3 print issues of The Carriers (all of which are available as donation rewards). This is MY PRIDE AND JOY! I LOVE PUTTING TOGETHER AND PUBLISHING COMICS! (Sorry for the over-use/abuse of the caps lock key.) I am working on getting the 4th and 5th chapters done for what will (if this project gets funded)- The Collected Edition of The Carriers. 
Your help in funding this project will make the creation and publishing of The Collected Edition of The Carriers possible. 
So if you are interested in helping this project to reality, take the time to donate and get some cool incentives as an added bonus.
Check out this article for more information about The Carriers-
http://www.bleedingcool.com/2011/03/21/more-awesome-booths-at-c2e2-by-samantha-lafountain/
I thought that I would show some of my process that I use for creating the artwork for The Carriers
I start by doing the layout in Photoshop. This allows me to make adjustments to the layout without destroying the piece in its early stages. 
The next step is to take that image and print it to bristol board. I take the ghost image printed in blue ink and use india ink to ink the page. I like this part the most because it is at this point that I have created something tangible. An object rather than just a pretty picture on a computer screen.
I scan that then lay in colors. 
Then all I do is refine the rough color drawing into a finished painting. I will bounce between a few programs to get various effects that make my paintings look the way they do. I do a few adjustments to get the mood and color balance just right and that's all it takes.

CONCEPT: This is a new technology, experimental film that consists of digital timelapse imagery set in the forests of the Pacific Northwest. The concept is to make one continuous timelapse shot following the night and day sky over the span of an entire day, 24 hours. The film is called “Warm Earth, Which I’ve Been Told” and is built around music by Six Organs of Admittance, who have generously given me their full support and music rights for this film. The entire film will be shot on a digital camera with a 180º circular fisheye lens (brand new Canon lens technology), allowing the entire horizon and sky to be visible in frame. 
The fisheye will contain the images in a circle, representing the shape of the earth, a repeating theme throughout the film. Likewise the distortion of a fisheye lens will add an interesting abstractness to the images making an entirely unique and compelling work of art. 
STORY: It begins at noon looking straight up at the sun and sky. Trees stretch from the outside of the circle toward the center where they part, displaying the entire sky. Voices chant “where will I rest” as the sun continues to set and clouds flow by. At the 4:50 mark, the sun sets behind the horizon. Then the music shifts to a tranquil/cosmic section. Here the camera will display the entire rotating night sky and Milky Way galaxy, silhouetted by lunging trees. At 12:50 in the film, the music begins to shift again into an ominous chant as the sun starts to rise. The camera follows the sun up above at noon under the trees at the same place where the film began (representing the looping/spherical pattern of life).
FUNDING: To help pay for and recoup the costs for making the film and the equipment required. Those costs include the camera, lens, battery and data storage for shooting 24 hours straight in a remote location. For $5,000 I will able to produce, film, edit, and complete this unique HD film that will be shown throughout the world.
PUBLIC SCREENINGS:
FESTIVALS: I have had my films shown in over 30 international film festivals and plan to use those connections to screen this film in many festivals around the world.
PLANETARIUMS: I am already in discussion with screening this in many planetariums and welcome the opportunity to inspire and educate audiences with this unique glimpse of a day passing.
ONLINE: I will offer a full HD version of the film available free online with vimeo.
